column2: Apptrian Extensions

column1: Pinterest Pixel
column2: Pinterest Pixel

column1: About
column2: About

column1: General
column2: General

column1: Enabled
column2: Enabled

column1: Enables or disables the extension.
column2: Enables or disables the extension.

column1: Pinterest Pixel ID
column2: Pinterest Pixel ID

column1: Your Pinterest Pixel ID or comma-separated IDs. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Your Pinterest Pixel ID or comma-separated IDs. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1:
You can use multiple pixels and they will track the same information. There is no limit on the number of IDs. However, Pinterest does not recommend using multiple pixels on the same page.
"Using the track function on pages that have multiple pixels initialized (either using multiple base codes or even combining it within one base code) could produce over-firing or unexpected behavior and should be applied only in specific situations."
column2:
You can use multiple pixels and they will track the same information. There is no limit on the number of IDs. However, Pinterest does not recommend using multiple pixels on the same page.
"Using the track function on pages that have multiple pixels initialized (either using multiple base codes or even combining it within one base code) could produce over-firing or unexpected behavior and should be applied only in specific situations."

column1: Add Pinterest Pixel To
column2: Add Pinterest Pixel To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want Pinterest Pixel.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want Pinterest Pixel.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want Pinterest Pixel to appear.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want Pinterest Pixel to appear.

column1: Enable Pinterest Pixel Base Code
column2: Enable Pinterest Pixel Base Code

column1: Enable Pinterest Pixel base code. WARNING! See the tooltip.
column2: Enable Pinterest Pixel base code. WARNING! See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables Pinterest Pixel base code. The base code is required for Pinterest Pixel to function.
column2: This option enables Pinterest Pixel base code. The base code is required for Pinterest Pixel to function.

column1: Enable noscript Tag
column2: Enable noscript Tag

column1: Enable noscript tag. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable noscript tag. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables noscript tag. The noscript tag defines an alternate content to be displayed to users that have disabled scripts in their browser or have a browser that does not support scripts. There is no need for noscript tag because Magento requires scripts to function.
column2: This option enables noscript tag. The noscript tag defines an alternate content to be displayed to users that have disabled scripts in their browser or have a browser that does not support scripts. There is no need for noscript tag because Magento requires scripts to function.

column1: Enable First-Party Cookies
column2: Enable First-Party Cookies

column1: Enable first-party cookies. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable first-party cookies. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables first-party cookies. The Pinterest tag creates and accesses cookies in a first-party context on your site domain, providing better visibility into the Pinterest traffic on your site. If you want to delete the first-party cookies, set this option to "No". When you do this our extension will add 'fp_cookie': false to the Pinterest initialization code.
column2: This option enables first-party cookies. The Pinterest tag creates and accesses cookies in a first-party context on your site domain, providing better visibility into the Pinterest traffic on your site. If you want to delete the first-party cookies, set this option to "No". When you do this our extension will add 'fp_cookie': false to the Pinterest initialization code.

column1: Enable Metadata Enrichment
column2: Enable Metadata Enrichment

column1: Enable metadata enrichment. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable metadata enrichment. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables metadata enrichment. If you are using catalogs and shopping ads to showcase your products, Pinterest will use the tag to automatically update your product information to match the information on your website. This is referred to as metadata enrichment. If you want to disable the metadata enrichment, set this option to "No". When you do this our extension will add 'md_frequency': 0 to the Pinterest initialization code.
column2: This option enables metadata enrichment. If you are using catalogs and shopping ads to showcase your products, Pinterest will use the tag to automatically update your product information to match the information on your website. This is referred to as metadata enrichment. If you want to disable the metadata enrichment, set this option to "No". When you do this our extension will add 'md_frequency': 0 to the Pinterest initialization code.

column2: Enable AddToCart Event

column1: Enable AddToCart event. See the tooltip.
column2: Enable AddToCart event. See the tooltip.

column1: This option enables the firing of the event. This is done with JavaScript in your visitor/customer web browser by the Pinterest Pixel.
column2: This option enables the firing of the event. This is done with JavaScript in your visitor/customer web browser by the Pinterest Pixel.

column1: Detect Selected SKU
column2: Detect Selected SKU

column1: Try to detect selected SKUs for products. WARNING! See the tooltip!
column2: Try to detect selected SKUs for products. WARNING! See the tooltip!

column1: This feature is heavily dependent on the theme you are using and its customization. It is impossible to predict all possible themes and customizations. Because of this detection will not work on every theme. This is why extension default configuration comes with this feature turned off. You can turn it on, try it out if it is working for you and if it does leave it on, otherwise turn it off. If you are a developer you will be pleased to know that everything is conveniently located in code.phtml file. To make it work, in some cases only the adjustment of few jQuery selectors is needed in others complete rewrite of detection code is needed. Because of this, we do not give any warranty for the detection feature, nor it is covered by our support service.
column2: This feature is heavily dependent on the theme you are using and its customization. It is impossible to predict all possible themes and customizations. Because of this detection will not work on every theme. This is why extension default configuration comes with this feature turned off. You can turn it on, try it out if it is working for you and if it does leave it on, otherwise turn it off. If you are a developer you will be pleased to know that everything is conveniently located in code.phtml file. To make it work, in some cases only the adjustment of few jQuery selectors is needed in others complete rewrite of detection code is needed. Because of this, we do not give any warranty for the detection feature, nor it is covered by our support service.

column1: Category (Category Page)
column2: Category (Category Page)

column1: Add Category-Related Code To
column2: Add Category-Related Code To

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want category-related code. See the tooltip.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want category-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_category_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add category-related code.
This option only works for category page handles where category object is set.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_category_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add category-related code.
This option only works for category page handles where category object is set.

column1: Event Name
column2: Event Name

column1: Type event name you want to use for category tracking. See the tooltip.
column2: Type event name you want to use for category tracking. See the tooltip.

column1: The proper event should be viewcategory. Leave this option to empty if you want only page event on category pages. Recommendation is to set this option to empty or use viewcategory.
column2: The proper event should be viewcategory. Leave this option to empty if you want only page event on category pages. Recommendation is to set this option to empty or use viewcategory.

column1: Category Parameters to Attributes Mapping
column2: Category Parameters to Attributes Mapping

column1: If you want to add custom parameters to categories. Please see the tooltip.
column2: If you want to add custom parameters to categories. Please see the tooltip.

column1:
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Pinterest Pixel parameter and Magento category attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.
column2:
Example: gpc=gpc|color=color
As you can see the format is simple
param1=attribute1|param2=attribute2
Pinterest Pixel parameter and Magento category attribute are connected by = sign and pairs are separated by | sign.

column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want product-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add product-related code.
This option only works for product page handles where current_product is set in the registry.
column2:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, catalog_product_view
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add product-related code.
This option only works for product page handles where current_product is set in the registry.

column1: For Bundle Products Use
column2: For Bundle Products Use

column1: Select SKU you want to use for bundle products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for bundle products. See the tooltip.

column1:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'
column2:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs

{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}

{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU

Children SKUs

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

column1: For Grouped Products Use
column2: For Grouped Products Use

column1: Select SKU you want to use for grouped products. See the tooltip.
column2: Select SKU you want to use for grouped products. See the tooltip.

column1:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

The Product SKU option is not recommended because of the nature of grouped products in Magento. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."
column2:
Examples with contents:

Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', quantity: 1}
]

Children SKUs and Product SKU
contents: [
{id: 'SHBP-6-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-7-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1},
{id: 'SHBP-8-BL', item_group_id: 'SHBP', quantity: 1}
]

Examples with content_ids:

Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP']

Children SKUs
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL']

Children SKUs and Product SKU
content_ids: ['SHBP-6-BL', 'SHBP-7-BL', 'SHBP-8-BL'],
item_group_id: 'SHBP'

The Product SKU option is not recommended because of the nature of grouped products in Magento. From Magento documentation: "Although they are presented as a group, each product in the group is purchased as a separate item. In the shopping cart, each item and the quantity purchased appears as a separate line item."

column1: Use Magento Quote ID For Parameter
column2: Use Magento Quote ID For Parameter

column1: Type parameter name for which you want to use Magento quote ID. Example: quote_id
column2: Type parameter name for which you want to use Magento quote ID. Example: quote_id

column1:
Magento quote ID is internal database table auto increment ID.
Example: 3275

If you do not want to use parameter for Magento quote ID leave this field empty.
column2:
Magento quote ID is internal database table auto increment ID.
Example: 3275

If you do not want to use parameter for Magento quote ID leave this field empty.

column1: Type page handles (full action names) where you want order-related code. See the tooltip.
column2: Type page handles (full action names) where you want order-related code. See the tooltip.

column1:
The page handles - Synonyms of the page type identifiers. Correspond to "full action names" of controller actions, for example, checkout_onepage_success
In this option you would type all handles where you want to add order-related code.

column1:
Magento order ID is internal database table auto increment ID.

If you do not want to use parameter for Magento order ID leave this field empty.

column1: Use Magento Order Increment ID For Parameter
column2: Use Magento Order Increment ID For Parameter

column2: Type parameter name for which you want to use Magento order increment ID. Example: order_id

column1:
Magento order increment ID is what you see in order emails, Magento Admin and which you communicate to your customer.

If you do not want to use parameter for Magento order increment ID leave this field empty.
column2:
Magento order increment ID is what you see in order emails, Magento Admin and which you communicate to your customer.
Example: 000001586

column2: The proper event name is Search.

column1: Parameter Name
column2: Parameter Name

column1: Type parameter name you want to use for search tracking. See the tooltip.
column2: Type parameter name you want to use for search tracking. See the tooltip.

column1: The proper parameter name is search_string.
column2: The proper parameter name is search_string.

column1: Request Parameters
column2: Request Parameters

column1: Type request parameters you want to include for search tracking. See the tooltip.
column2: Type request parameters you want to include for search tracking. See the tooltip.

column1:
Example: q,name,sku,description,
short_description.
If only q request parameter exists then only its value will be used. If multiple request parameters exist their values will be concatenated with a comma sign in between.
column2:
Example: q,name,sku,description,
short_description.
